Microwave assisted green synthesis of Zwitterionic photolumenescent Ndoped carbon dots: An efficient ‘on-off’ chemosensor for tracer Cr(+6) considering the inner filter effect and nano drug-delivery vector
Sayan Gangulya,1, Poushali Dasb,1, Subhayan Dasc, Uttamkumar Ghoraid, Madhuparna Bosee, Sabyasachi Ghosha, Mahitosh Mondalc, Amit Kumar Dase, Susanta Banerjeeb,f, Narayan Ch Dasa,b,⁎
a Rubber Technology Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur 721302, India b School of Nanoscience and Technology, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur 721302, India c School of Medical Science and Technology, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur 721302, India dDepartment of Industrial Chemistry and Applied Chemistry, Ramakrishna Mission Vidyamandira, Belur Math, Howrah 711202, India e Department of Biotechnology, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur 721302, India fMaterials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur 721302, India
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Hexavalent chromium Microwave Inner filter effect Drug release
A B S T R A C T
Hexavalent chromium (Cr(+6)) has been considered as a terrible pollutant because of its toxicity and carcinogenic features. Herein, a tracer Cr(+6) sensing carbon nanodots has been prepared by microwave mediated thermal coupling of melamine and L-arginine. This present study determined the ‘on-off’ fluorescence behavior for determining the Cr(+6) obeying the inner filter effect (IFE). To prove the versatility, the size stability and photostability were also performed in phosphate buffer and fetal bovine serum media. Moreover, the nanodots surface ligands are quite susceptible to capture drug molecules which also have been tested by pH-tunable cumulative drug release method.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heavy metal pollution is the most common fact of water pollution throughout the whole world. Among these heavy metals, chromium is one of the dangerous metals obtained as a byproduct of industrial (electroplating, leather, metal polishing/finishing, photography, mining, battery, dues and pigments and textiles) and anthropogenic methods [1]. The most hazardous in the chromium subclass is the hexavalent chromium or chromium (+6) or chromate [2]. Hexavalent chromium has been taken as more vulnerable than Cr(+3) because of their carcinogenic character and enormous mobility in living organisms [3]. As per WHO (World Health Organization), the tolerable limit for Cr (+6) in drinking water is 0.05mg L−1 (1 μM) [4]. Nonetheless, Cr(+6) is highly mobile and it can traverses throughout the ecosystems [5]. It also has a tendency to accumulate in living cells/tissues and food chains [6]. Thus the precise detection of Cr(+6) in drinking water and other ecosystem components cannot be ruled out. There are several analytical tools which can detect Cr(+6) in aqueous medium like spectrophotometry [7], inductively coupled plasma-mass spectroscopy (ICPMS), spectrofluorimetry [8], atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) [9], and diffuse reluctance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRFTIR) etc. [10]. All these above mentioned tools are capable of precise detection of Cr(+6) but the main problem is their operating and installation cost. In that aspect, simple fluorescence assisted quenching chemistry has been adopted for fast and precise quantitative estimation of Cr(+6).
Zero dimensional fascinating class of quasi-spherical nanocarbon with size below 10 nm;have been nurtured since a few years because of their outstanding fluorescent characters,very low toxicity and cytocompatibility [11–13]. These exotic carbon dots (CDs) have been widely applied in the fields of light emitting devices [14], antibacterial property [15], sensor [16–20], catalysis [11,21], sustainable bio-imaging and cellular imaging [22,23]. The photoluminescence (PL) behaviour of the CDs has high dependency over their sizes, composites, doping, morphologies and the way of their fabrication [24]. Chemical doping is a proved phenomenon to enhance the quantum yield of the CDs; besides unique surface features, polarity, PL behaviour and electrochemical attributes [24,25]. For these reasons chemical doping, especially N atom has been doped via choosing of the nitrogenous precursors materials [26–29]. It has been already proved that amine groups present in precursor materials can raise their quantum yield up to10% [30]. Hence N-rich CDs become very much acceptable due to superior PL behaviours with respect to undoped CDs [31]. To prepare CDs, there are several synthesis routes applied by researchers like solvothermal treatment [32], pyrolysis [33], thermal coupling [34] and microwave-assisted method [35,36]. Microwave assisted pyrolysis is a fast and green method to prepared CDs where no rigorous reaction conditions have been required. Several researchers already reported the effect of microwave to synthesis CDs from various carbonaceous precursors [37,38]. Regarding their low toxicity, tunable excitation and emission spectra, and high photostability make them as a good chemosensor. But still there are drawbacks that curb extensive applicability of CDs. The basic rule of thumb regarding the mechanism of chemosensing abide by in the molecular level where interactions between CDs surface ligands and target species are taken place. But these strategies are relatively delayed responding which restricts the immense usage of the carbon dots In practical fields [39]. In this aspect, one thing is worth mentioning that the primary quality of CDs is their quantum yield (QY) which attributes to evaluate whether the CDs are preferable or not. Hence, CDs with high QY have to be designed for fluorescent assay using an alternative mechanism. Inner filter effect (IFE) is an intrinsic quenching process in the detection system [40]. It is becoming more prominent when detectable quencher molecules re-absorb the light which results poor fluorescence signal. In this area to obtain better fluorescence, doping is quite inevitable. Nitrogen was found to be the most easy to obtain as dopant from low cost precursors and highly
abundant. Herein, nitrogen rich precursor materials have been chosen to prepare N-doped CDs. As a common nitrogenous organic base, melamine can be a suitable choice as a precursor material. Melamine is a cyclic trimer of cyanamide having a 1,3,5-triazine skeleton containing 67% of N atoms. It has amine functionalities (3 per molecules of melamine), thus it has high propensity to condensate with carboxylic acids, hydroxyl and ketones. In a previous report by Wang et al., melamine and glycerol can be thermal coupling in presence of catalyst having 22% quantum yield [41]. Melamine was also coupled with citric acid (carboxyl coupling-quantum yield 41.5%) [42], glutaraldehyde (carbonyl coupling-quantum yield 31%) to achieve high quantum yield (QY) and PL character [43]. Besides these chemo-sensing activities of CDs have enough potential to be served as drug delivery vehicle in the nanodimension due to its low toxicity, specific selectivity towards target and desirable drug efficacy with respect to other conventional drug delivery systems [44]. According to several literatures, fluorescent CDs are highly capable in this field because of their well-defined quasi-spherical shapes, high surface area, easy drug attachment and defined release kinetics’ selectivity.
Inspiring from the literatures we herein develop melamine based carbon dots with a zwitter ionic molecule, L-arginine. L-arginine being an amino acid, also possess N atom which can again boost the doping of carbon dots. We used green process (microwave irradiation) to couple melamine and L-arginine to get quasi-spherical CDs particles having size around 1.5–4.5 nm. High amount of N doping of this prepared CDs gives relatively high QY of approximately 58.4% which is quite superior to the aforementioned reported CDs. Moreover, the PL behaviours were also studied in a wide pH range of 2.0 to 12.0 which exhibited almost constant PL behaviours. The drug release study was also perfumed and fitted in release kinetic models.

sections.heading: 2.1. Morphology and physical properties of MANCDs
sections.text:
The preparation strategy of carbon dots by melamine and L-arginine has been illustrated in Fig. 1a (synthesis procedure has been given in Supporting information). Covalent coupling was applied here to prepare water dispersible carbon dots. The period of microwave irradiation was changed keeping the ratio of melamine and L-arginine constant. The time of irradiation was taken as 5min, 8min, and 12min. after irradiation, the amine groups of melamine was condensed with the carboxylic acid group of L-arginine to form N-doped carbon dots (MANCDs). As per the microwave heating, the contained MANCDs were designated as MANCDs-X; where ‘X’ is the time of irradiation in min.
High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) provides the spherical morphology of the prepared MANCDs. As shown in HRTEM images (Fig. S1a), the MANCDs particles are spherical in shape [42]. The size of the MANCDs was ranges between 1.5–4.5 nm with an abundance of 2.5 nm. The statistical analysis of dispersed MANCDs in grid has been plotted by bar-diagram shown in Fig. 1b. The AFM images (Fig. S1b) revealed the height of MANCDs was around 3.42 nm implicates quasi-spherical type particles.
Surface chemical analysis of the MANCDs was performed by XPS analysis as shown in Fig. 1c. The XPS survey scan showed characteristic peaks at 284, 402 and 531 eV indicating C, N and O elemental proof in MANCDs respectively. High resolution XPS of C1s (Fig. 1d) revealed main peaks at 284.6, 285.4, 287.2 and 288.3 eV. These peaks implied the CeC, CeN, C]O/C]N, and OeC]O (sp2) bonds respectively [45]. N1s peaks at 400 eV and 409.9 eV exhibited relatively lower intensity peak for CeN (sp3) and NeH (sp3) respectively which is shown in Fig. 1e. O1s core level spectra exhibited peak at 532.6 eV (CeOH/ CeOeC) and 531.4 eV (C]O) also provides the information of the presence of oxygen in the carbon dots (Fig.1f).
The presence of functional groups in MANCDs was studied by FTIR spectrum as shown in Fig. 2a.The characteristic broadening at 3117 and 3476 cm−1 are due to the stretching of primary amine (eNH2) peaks of the surface ligands L-arginine. The distinctive peaks at 1557 and 1632 cm−1 imply the bending vibration of amide linkage (eCONHe) inherited from thermal coupling between melamine eNH2 and eCOOH group of L-arginine. The characteristic peak of amine III (CeN) is also observed around 1460 cm−1.Other typical peaks at 813, 1010, and 1362 cm−1 arise from the out of plane bending vibration of benzene CeH and stretching vibrations of CeO functionalities present in the MANCDs.

sections.heading: 2.2. Optical properties and stability of MANCDs
sections.text:
To explore the effect of surface passivation on the optical properties of the CDs, their UV–vis absorption and photoluminescence properties were studied. The aqueous solution of the CDs shows characteristic absorption peaks at 288 nm in the UV–vis spectrum (Fig.2b). The absorption peak located at 288 nm is ascribed to the π-π* transition of an aromatic system which is reminiscent of sp2-hybridized network from the carbon core.
The aqueous solution of the CDs is light yellow under sunlight (left), whereas it emits bright blue fluorescence (right) at365 nm UV light irradiation (Fig. 2b inset). The aqueous solution of the CDs is transparent under ambient condition which indicates good aqueous dispersibility of the CDs due to large number of hydrophilic groups attached at the surface of the CDs. The CDs display maximum emission intensity around 404 nm (a bright blue emission) when excited at 340 nm. The photoluminescence emission of the as prepared CDs exhibits excitation-dependent behavior. As depicted in Fig. 2c the emission peak of the as prepared CDs becomes red-shifted (from 385 to 508 nm) with increasing the excitation wavelength from 320 to 460 nm. This feature enables the multicolor fluorescence which arises not only from the size distribution but also from the distribution of different emissive trap site [46]. The multicolor luminescence feature of the CDs is the reason of heterogeneity of CDs comprising chromophores at different energy levels is reported elsewhere [47]. The fluorescence quantum yield was calculated to be about 58.4% using quinine sulfate in 0.1M H2SO4 as standard (λex= 360 nm). The FL quantum yield
value obtained is relatively higher than several reports in earlier times which have been tallied in Table S1. The Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagram of the prepared MANCDs is shown in Fig. 2d. The excitation dependent CIE (x, y) coordinates shift was observed for MANCDs which are located at (0.16810, 0.09503), (0.16598, 0.09176), (0.16548, 0.10318), (0.16781, 0.13295), (0.17444, 0.19180), (0.18746, 0.26963), (0.21608, 0.38589) and (0.28156, 0.053414) for 320, 340, 360, 380, 400, 420,440 and 460 nm respectively. The time resolved spectroscopic study was performed to determine the lifetime decay of the fluorescent MANCDs as shown in Fig. 2e. The time dependent decay was calculated after fitting the decay plot to double exponential decay equation as written below;

The calculated average lifetime was around 7.8 ns. The nanosecond magnitude of fluorescence lifetime indicates that the CDs were suitable for biological and optoelectronic applications [48].
One of the most important properties of the CDs is their stability in various environmental conditions. The fluorescence intensity of the CDs remains stable even more than 9 months in dark place at 4 °C and 3 months at room temperature (Fig. 2f). We studied the effect of ionic strength on the stability of CDs using different concentration of NaCl in 10mM PBS (pH=7.4) solution. It was found that the fluorescence signal was scarcely changed in a wide range (0–2M) of NaCl concentrations (Fig. 2g). The photoluminescence properties of the CDs in different pH solutions were examined. Fig. 2h shows that CDs unveils strong fluorescence intensity in the pH range 4–11 when excited at 340 nm. At the lower pH the decrease of fluorescence intensity was due to the protonation of the surface functional groups of the CDs. Also, the fluorescence intensity of the nano-dots was not affected under continuous excitation at 365 nm UV light for 2 h (Fig. 2i). All the features suggested excellent photostability of the as prepared CDs, which has wide application in various fields and under different conditions.

sections.heading: 2.3. Quenching mechanism in presence of Cr(+6)
sections.text:
The Cr(+6) causes major decreasing trend in FL intensity of the MANCDs (Fig. 3a; magnified image has been given in Fig. 3b). We are digging into the plausible mechanistic pathway behind this quenching phenomenon. As shown in Fig. S2, Cr(+6) has three major peaks at 260, 350 and 450 nm in the UV–vis spectrum. Moreover, the MANCDs showed excitation wavelength at 340 nm and emission wavelength at ˜410 nm. Though the spectral overlap between absorption band of quencher (here Cr(+6)) and excitation/emission wavelength of the asprepared fluorescent chemosensor was taken place here, the effect of inner filter effect (IFE) cannot be ruled out. The quenching mechanism might be an outcome of chelation between MANCDs surface ligands and Cr(+6) cation (Fig. 3c). Cr(+6) might bind to groups containing oxygen, such as carboxyl or phenolic groups present on the surface of MANCDs. To gain an insight into the quenching mechanism we recorded the fluorescence intensities of the MANCDs/Cr(+6) system in presence and absence of a strong metal chelating agent (Na2EDTA). The black column in Fig. S3 showed the fluorescence intensity of the MANCDs solution in presence of Cr(+6) (mixed solution) before adding Na2EDTA, and the red column revealed the fluorescence intensity of the mixed solution after the addition of Na2EDTA. The results showed that the fluorescence intensities of the mixed solutions before and after addition of Na2EDTA were hardly changed. Na2EDTA cannot chelate
with Cr(VI) from MANCDs, which indicated that MANCDs holds potential ability as a metal chelating agent. Similar type of quenching phenomenon also had been discussed in various reported literatures elsewhere [49]. IFE is occurred whenever intersystem photon absorbers and scatterers resulting spectral non-linearity and distortion in actual FL data. Theoretically the IFE can be neglected if the UV–vis spectral intensity is as low as 0.05 (i.e. ˜5%) at the FL excitation/emission spectral domain. In our case the UV–vis spectral intensity was significantly high than the reported values, thus corrections for IFE is a major belonging to deemmore precise spectral data. Hypothetical investigation has been taken place after granting the cuvette geometry and UV–vis absorption features of the Cr(+6) mixed MANCDs system. Fig. 3d is the classifiable pictorial representation of configured spectrofluorophotometer where the source and emitted photons collector are laying the right angle. Thus, the excitation and emission optical pathways can show distinct photon counts at different sampling points. Hence, IFE can dissimilar from one sampling point to another for identical excitation and emission intensity. The IFE was corrected as per the following equation;

sections.heading: 2.4. Optimization of experimental conditions
sections.text:
Being hazardous Cr(+6) have attracted serious concerns since it extensively present in industrial leftover. Based on the fact that Cr(+6) can quench the fluorescence response of MANCDs, we attempt to employ MANCDs as a luminescent podium for Cr(+6) sensing. As pH plays a significant character in the form of Cr (+6) and fluorescence signal of MANCDs the influences of fluorescence to pH was initially considered. Herein, to evaluate the ability of MANCDs in the sensitive detection of Cr(+6), the term fluorescence quenching efficiency (F0-F1)/F0was introduced, where F0 represents the original fluorescence intensity of the MANCDs and F1 denotes the fluorescence intensity in presence of Cr (+6). The influence of pH in the sensing of Cr(+6) was carried out in
PBS buffer. From Fig. 4a it can be seen that with increasing pH, (F0-F1)/ F0value increases and attained its maximum when at pH 11. In aqueous solution the form of Cr(+6) species depends on the pH of the solution. In acidic condition, Cr(+6) existed in the form of Cr2O72− and in basic environment (pH 11) CrO42− becomes dominating [50]. Increment in fluorescent quenching efficiency could be accredited to the Cr(+6) species-induced changes of the UV–vis spectrum. In alkaline condition, the absorbance around288 nm and 364 nm was augmented (Fig. 4b) resulting increment in quenching efficiency of Cr(+6)abide by IFE mechanism. The quenching efficiency, (F0-F1)/F0, is a crucial factor for chemosensing activity. The incubation time for the Cr(+6) and MANCDs system is kept around 180 s (3min) which is reasonably fast and comparable to other reported systems. To obtain the best sensing result, the effect of reaction time and temperature was also investigated on the sensing ability of the MANCDs. As mentioned in Fig. 4c the quenching kinetics of Cr(+6) on the fluorescence response of the MANCDs was monitored. In this figure, the concentration of Cr(+6) was kept constant at 200 μM. The plot showed almost immediate response for the MANCDs in presence of Cr(+6) in aqueous system. After ˜3min, the plot plateaued off inferring to the homogeneity in response data. This means the MANCDs have no such severe time dependency in the Cr(+6) sensing behavior.

sections.heading: 2.5. Determination of Cr(+6)
sections.text:
Under these optimized conditions the detailed sensing performance of the MANCDs was discussed. The emission spectra of the MANCDs were recorded after addition of different concentration of the Cr(+6). The intensity of the emission spectra centered at 450 nm gradually decreased with increasing concentrations of Cr(+6) from 0 to 300μM. Fig. 4d depicted the relationship between quenching efficiency and Cr (+6) concentrations. A good linear correlation obtained over the concentration range from 1 to 150 μM and the linear regression equation was (F0- F1)/F0= 0.00259x + 0.03781 with the goodness of fit R2 = 0.98467 (Fig. 4d-inset). The limit of detection (LOD) was calculated to be 0.53 μM using three times standard deviation rule (LOD=3σ/S, S

Iobs=observed fluorescence intensity, Icorr=corrected fluorescence intensity after removing IFE); Icorr0 = corrected fluorescence intensity of MANCDs without Cr(+6).
stands for the slope of the calibration curve and σ is the standard deviation of 9 blank samples), which was better than many other fluorescent probes reported (Table 2). On the other hand, for maximum studies represented in Table 2, the linear range of Cr (VI) concentration were narrow, which restricted the quantitative analysis in higher concentration. In contrast, the MANCDs exhibited comparatively lower LOD but broader linear range for Cr (VI) detection which has more prospective in monitoring Cr (VI) concentration. Moreover, as MANCDs are metal free nanoparticles it is very safe to employ in biological fields. According to World Health Organization (WHO) the permissible limit of Cr(+6) concentration should be controlled below 50 μg/L (0.96μM) [51].
These outcomes indicated that MANCDs is enough sensitive to detect Cr(+6) in drinking water. To assess the selectivity of MANCDs for sensitive detection of Cr(+6), the fluorescence intensity of MANCDs was studied in the presence of different environmentally relevant metal ions. As presented in Fig. 4e, under the same conditions noteworthy fluorescence quenching was found after addition of Cr(+6); whereas for the other metal ions very minute fluorescence quenching or improvement was detected and this deviation was almost negligible. This describes the high selectivity of the MANCDs for fluorescent sensing of Cr(+6). Furthermore, the impacts of these interfering metal ions on Cr (+6) sensing were examined to validate its applicability in environmental water samples. The metal ions concentrations were taken five times higher than the Cr(+6) concentration for this experiment. The influence of other metal ions were almost negligible (Fig.4f) in comparison to the effective quenching of Cr(+6). This suggested that Cr
(+6) had a strong affinity towards the carboxylic functionalities present at the surface of the MANCDs than other metal ions [52].

sections.heading: 2.6. Analysis in real water samples
sections.text: The MANCDs based fluorescent nano-probe was employed for determination of Cr(+6) in real drinking water and river water samples. The recovery experiments were carried out using a standard addition method. For river water, the sample recoveries were estimated between 88–112% and the relative standard deviations (RSDs) were in the range of 0.69 and 1.71(Table3). In the meantime, for tap water there coveries were between 83–104%, with the RSD varied in the range 0.9–1.58% (Table 4).In one word, using MANCDs to sense Cr(+6) in real water is easy and inexpensive, but also affords accurate and sensitive measurement.

sections.heading: 2.7. In vitro cytocompatibility assessment of the MANCDs nanoparticles
sections.text: Fig. 5a represents to the in vitro cell growth study of human dermal fibroblasts after 24 h and 73 h in presence of MANCDs nanoparticles and in tissue culture plate (TCP). The cell viability was checked in terms of killing of cells in presence of sample. The viability is a direct reflection of cell metabolism. MTT assay depicts that very negligible amount of cell killing was observed. The killing was increasing with increasing the MANCDs concentration (Fig. 5b). The cell death also showed minimal differences after 24 h and 72 h of study. After 24 h and 72 h the cell morphology was intact which implied desirable cell grown and cell attachment of cells in presence of nanoparticles were taken place. This study implies non-cytotoxicity of fibroblasts cell lines.

sections.heading: 2.8. Size stability analysis
sections.text:
The size stability is a major assessment of nanoparticles in colloidal dimension. Herein, further evaluation of the stability has been estimated of MANCDs in aqueous dispersion. The size of the MANCDs has been estimated from the DLS experiment derived plot as shown in Fig. 6(a–f). Initially the DLS data corroborated that the average size of the MANCDs were 2.4 nm. The timed monitoring of size is also has another significance of stability. Herein, the DLS study also had been evaluated for 3 weeks which results nominal change in MANCDs diameter. This implied excellent stability of prepared MANCDs in aqueous environment which also can draw conclusion in support of long ‘shelflife’ of MANCDs. For betterment of understanding of size stability, we also carried out of the similar kind of experiment taking fetal bovine serum (FBS) as MANCDs’ dispersing agent. That was implemented because cell culture and other in vitro/vivo experimentations are normally performed in FBS medium. In FBS media it was seen that the average size of the MANCDs were almost identical in water/PBS media. But for prolonged storage of MANCDs in FBS media the hydrodynamic diameter was negligibly enhanced compared to PBS or water. This can be
hypothesized that being a supramolecular structure of FBS, the surface dominant physisorption of those long chains of FBS cannot be ruled out. This resulted very negligible qualitative heightening of MANCDs size as per the DLS data. The comparison of size between the PBS and FBS media had been revealed in Fig. 6g. Moreover, the extent of photobleaching was also carried out in present of white light for 60min. at a stretch. In this case for relative comparison, we kept Rhodamine B as a model commercially used synthetic dye for cell culture experiments. From Fig. 6(h,i), it was observed that there were no remarkable gradual deterioration in UV–vis and fluorescence intensities. It infers again the excellent storage life of MANCDs with respect to other commercially available synthetic dyes.
2.9. In vitro drug release study and data fitting
The model drug, diltiazem hydrochloride (DTZ) was loaded on MANCDs (0.527mg/mL) by physical mixing of diltiazem hydrochloride in water. The evidence of drug loading was confirmed by UV–vis (Fig. 7a) and FL spectra (Fig. 7b). As shown in Fig. 7a, pure DTZ and MANCDs have λmax of 236 nm and 288 nm respectively. For DTZ bound MANCDs also showed both these absorption peaks were at 241 nm and 284 nm for DTZ and MANCDs respectively. That could infer the formation of drug-carbon complex. If the spectra would be closely seen, a slight blue shift of MANCDs spectral peak had been accounted. Such peak shift towards visible region could again support the drug-carbon dot complex formation. Besides this, red shift was another observation of the complex which implied n-π* and π-π* transition in DTZ-MANCDs conjugate. Such low energy electronic transitions are basically the outcome of H-bonding or polar-polar interactions. For betterment on the ground of drug-carbon dots conjugation, PL spectra were also discussed as shown in Fig. 7b. When the DTZ-MANCDs conjugate was excited at 360 nm, the PL spectra implied gradual time dependent increment in PL intensities. The result of drug release as per Fig. 5b has been used to evaluate the loading efficacy of MANCDs which was calculated to be 71.28%.
This high loading of drug into carbon dots has been implied to the desirable binding interactions between the DTZ and MANCDs. The mechanism of drug-CDs attachment has been pictorially illustrated in Fig. 7(c–e) which is a plausible attachment theory. Already the zeta potential values obtained and reported previously in this work which infers that the drug to CDs conjugation would be most desirable when the system was in pH around 7.4; i.e. in physiological condition. Zwitter ionic formation was developed in surface functionalities of MANCDs
because of the surface ligand applied here (L-arginine). As shown in Fig. 7c, the H-bonding and electrostatic interactions became most stringent in for nearly pH 7 whereas for low and high pH conditions those interactions were minimized due to the protonation and de-protonation phenomena respectively. The drug release experimentation was carried out at different time intervals for 3 days by utilizing dialysis bag. The drug release environment was taken as low pH, slight basic (pH 7.4) and highly basic. The aim of the study was to evaluate the impact of environment effect over drug release from MANCDs. Fig. 7f is the timed release plot of drug molecules as measured by UV–vis spectrophotometry. For control experiment the drug release was almost instantaneous due to its unbound state. Control experiment revealed greater than 85% drug release within 2 h of the experiment. This data is a proof for no hindrance caused by dialysis bag. For MANCDs and drug molecules mixed system, the drug release was not so fast like the control experiment which could imply the conjugation state of drug molecules and the carbon dots. The drug release data has been fitted to the following equation proposed by Peppas et al.
= =F M M K tt α n D P
Here Mt and Mα correspond to the drug release at finite time t and at equilibrium respectively. KP is proportionality constant (also called Peppas constant) and n is the diffusional coefficient, significance of the mechanism of drug release [61,62]. The drug release plot was shown in Fig. 7g. The value of the exponent ‘n’ lies below 0.5 which means the system was polydispesred having spherical shaped non-swellable particles. This inferred support of our previously embellished data where the characterizations also revealed the spherical shape of the carbon dots. In all the fitting the confidence limit were evaluated above 95%
which means suitable fitting of data in Peppas model for drug release. For the control experiment the burst release was seen which a common phenomenon for vector free delivery device. This means drug molecules were unable to anchor in carbon dots surface by means of any molecular attachment/interactions which tended the drug molecules release suddenly. Meanwhile for all others fitting it were also seen that initial stage release was quite fast but after certain time period the release was plateaued off. The loading and release of drug molecules from the carbon dots surface plausibly follows ‘conjugation and environment dependent discharge’ strategy. When drug molecules are come to close proximity to MANCDs surface, there is a high chance of conjugation in between MANCDs and drug. Additionally, the conjugation will be more facilitated when aromatic drug molecules have been chosen for model drug. In case of aromatic drug molecules, the conjugation is generally boosted by inter-pi electronic transition between carbon dots’ core and aromatic rings of drug molecules. The initial drug release is an outcome of concentration gradient between carbon dots’ surface and environment which was minimized after specific time period. This release is actually occurred in presence of environmental effects. When the environmental pH has been deviated, there is a gradual rupturing of secondary bonds (H-bonding/polar-polar interactions). Hypothetically, this can be proposed that the controlled delivery of drug molecules are more pronounced in the psychological pH, not even in very high/low pH environment. After specific time, the release is almost plateaued off which infers the onset of saturation in release kinetics resulting premature vector free delivery, i.e. in control experiment whereas for others that was completely eradicated.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, amino acid surface functionalized nitrogen doped high luminescent (QY˜58%) carbon dots was developed by microwave mediated method. The CDs were used to determine the Cr(+6) in aqueous medium. For testing the effectiveness of the CDs in sensing applications, the real sample analysis (river water and household tap water) was also carried out by taking the underlying inner filter effect (IFE) in fluorescence. The tracer Cr(+6) sending carbon dots based probe could measure the contaminant in low to high concentration. Besides the sensing applications, herein, the CDs were also tested for drug release and kinetics. The non-cytotoxicity of the CDs could promote for using it in biological applications. The size stability of the CDs is significant to assume their ‘shelf-life’ which was also evaluated here with a promising result.
